section.title: Introduction to NonChord Tones
section.p: Nonchord tonesnon-chord tonesdefinition of are notes that do not belong to the chord. Sometimes referred to as embellishing tones and nonharmonic tones, nonchord tones are classified by how they are approached and left (either by same tone, step, or leap).
There are nine types of nonchord tones.
The following qualifiers can be applied to nonchord tones:

li.p: Unaccentedoccuring on the weak part of the beat (on the offbeat)
Metricalequal to the duration of the beat

section.title: Passing Tones
section.p: Passing tones are notes that pass between chord tones.

figure.caption: Desrouleaux, Kirkpatrick, Martin, Robbins, Allan, Want to Want Me

section.p: In the first bar of the Want to Want Me example, the passing tone is unaccented. In the third bar, it is accented (on the beat). The nonchord tone in bar 2 is an appoggiatura.
There can be two consecutive diatonic passing tones in a descending scale segment from the root and fifth of a chord.

figure.caption: Hupfeld, As Time Goes By

idx.h: "As Time Goes By" (from the motion picture Casablanca)

section.p: Here is an example with chromatic passing tones.

figure.caption: Monk, Blue Monk

section.p: In the next section we discuss the neighbor tone.

section.title: Neighbor Tones
section.p: Neighbor tones move away from a note by step then return to the note.

figure.caption: Beethoven, Minuet in G, WoO 10, No. 2

section.p: In the next section we discuss the appogiatura.

section.title: Appoggiatura
section.p: The appoggiatura is approached by leap and left by step. It is usually accented (on the beat), which makes it a particularly expressive nonchord tone.

figure.caption: Horner and Jennings, My Heart Will Go On

idx.h: My Heart Will Go On (from Titanic)

section.p: The example above also has an anticipation, which is discussed in a later section in this chapter.

figure.caption: Springsteen, Born to Run

section.p: Notice that both the appoggiaturas in the following example resolve up. Both the leap to and step away from any appoggiatura can be from any direction.

figure.caption: Mozart, Symphony No. 40, K. 550, II

section.p: In the next section we discuss the escape tone.

section.title: Escape Tone
section.p: An escape tone is approached by step and left by leap in the opposite direction. An easy example to remember is the end of the StarSpangled Banner. The word of in home of the brave is an escape tone.

figure.caption: Key and Smith, StarSpangled Banner

section.p: Here is another example, with escape tones used in a melodic sequence.

figure.caption: Haydn, Sonata No. 48 in C Major, Hob. XVI: 35, III

idx.h: Sonata No. 48 in C Major, Hob. XVI: 35, III

section.p: Here is an example of an escape tone in popular music.

figure.caption: P. McCartney and L. McCartney, Silly Love Songs

section.title: Double Neighbor
section.p: The double neighbor (sometimes called a neighbor group) occur when both the upper and lower neighbor occur before the return to the starting tone.

figure.caption: C major arpeggio embellished with double neighbors
Kuhlau, Sonatina in C Major, Op. 55, No. 1, I

idx.h: Sonatina in C Major, Op. 55, No. 1, I

section.p: The double neighbor is sometimes confused with escape tones and appoggiaturas. Be sure to keep track of chord tones when analyzing nonchord tones. Look at the next example and ask yourself how you would analyze the harmony and non-chord tones on beat 4 of the first measure.

figure.caption: Mozart, Piano Sonata in Bb, K. 333, I

idx.h: Piano Sonata in Bb, K. 333, I

section.p: In the next section we discuss the anticipation.

section.title: Anticipation
section.p: An anticipation is a nonchord tone that anticipates the arrival of the next chord and is often found at cadences, as in the next example.

figure.caption: Handel, Rinaldo, Lascia ch'io pianga

idx.h: Piano Sonata in Bb, K. 333, I

section.p: Here is an example of an anticipation in popular music.

figure.caption: Harry and Moroder, Call Me

section.p: Sometimes syncopation will lead to an anticipation of a note in a chord in the following measure, as occurs at the ends of bars 1, 2, and 3 of the Call Me example.

section.title: Pedal Point
section.p: A pedal point is a note that is held through changing harmonies, starting as a chord tone before becoming a nonchord tone. Pedal points are often in the bass voice (the term pedal relates to the foot pedals on an organ).

figure.caption: Bach, J.S., WellTempered Clavier, Book I, Prelude 1 in C major

section.p: Here is an example from the Romantic era

figure.caption: Clara Schumann, Op. 13, No. 2, Sie liebten sich beide

idx.h: Op. 13, No. 2, Sie liebten sich beide

section.p: The Clara Schumann example above also has a suspension (3-2 sus.); suspensions are discussed in the next section.
When a pedal point is in the bass, it is not necessary to specify the inversion of the chord because the bass pedal point obscures the inversion.
You might also encounter a pedal point in a higher voice, as well as a double pedal point, where two notes (often a fifth apart) act as pedal points.

section.title: Suspension
section.p: Suspensions are accented nonchord tones occurring on downbeats. A suspension is approached by the same note and resolves down by step. A suspension is made up of a preparation, suspension, and resolution. Sometimes the preparation is tied to the suspension.

figure.caption: Introductory Suspension example with and without tie

section.p: Suspensions are classified by numbers (98, 76, 43, 23, and sometimes 65) that specify the interval distance of the suspended note and its resolution to the bass note

figure.caption: Examples of the 98, 76, 43, 23, and 65 suspensions

section.p: In the example above, the notes in the 43 suspension are an 11th and 10th higher than the bass. Reduce all intervals larger than an octave to the numbers 76, 43, and 65.
Here is an example with a 43 suspension.

figure.caption: Barber, Adagio for Strings

section.p: Here is an example with 76 and 98 suspensions.

figure.caption: Handel, Suite No. 2 in D Major, HWV 349: II

idx.h: Suite No. 2 in D Major, HWV 349: II

section.p: The 23 suspension is the bass suspension and is measured against an upper voice. Again, you may encounter the literal intervals 109 but should label the suspension as 23.

figure.caption: Bach, J.S., Liebster Jesu, wir sind hier, BWV 373

idx.h: Liebster Jesu, wir sind hier, BWV 373

section.p: When a chord is inverted, you will sometimes encounter non-standard suspension numbers like 54 or 32.

figure.caption: Nonstandard suspension numbers because of inverted chords

section.p: You will sometimes encounter decorations of suspensions where other notes occur before the resolution, as in the following example.

figure.caption: Bach, J.S., French Suite No. 1 in D Minor, BWV 812, Sarabande

idx.h: French Suite No. 1 in D Minor, BWV 812, Sarabande

section.p: The ret. in the tenor part in the second measure is a retardation, which is covered in the next section.

section.title: Retardation
section.p: A retardation is usually an accented nonchord tone, meaning it occurs on a downbeat. A retardation is approached by the same note and resolves up by step.

figure.caption: Mozart, Piano Sonata in C major, K. 545, II

idx.h: Piano Sonata in C major, K. 545, II

section.p: Classical composers like Mozart often used retardations and suspensions at cadences in slow movements.

section.title: Incomplete Neighbor
section.p: Because composers are notorious for breaking the rules, you will encounter examples in the real world that either defy explanation or have multiple valid explanations. One utility nonchord tone is the incomplete neighbor.

figure.caption: Puccini, Gianni Schicchi, O mio babbino caro

idx.h: Gianni Schicchi, O mio babbino caro

section.p: You may also find incomplete double neighbor figures, especially in late Romantic music and jazz. Keep an open mind when analyzing music.

section.title: Adding NonChord Tones to a Chord Progression
section.p:
Here are ideas for how to add nonchord tones (or embellishments) to the melody or inner voice part of a chord progression:
Repeated note: add upper or lower neighbor
Step down:
Add a suspension by delaying the resolution of the note
Add an escape tone by moving by step in the opposite direction of the original stepwise movement, then leap
Add a double neighbor
Add a chromatic passing tone
Add an anticipation
Step up:
Add retardation by delaying resolution of the note
Add a double neighbor
Add a chromatic passing tone
Add an anticipation
Add an appoggiatura by leaping one step beyond the note of resolution, placing the appogiatura on the beat, displacing the note of resolution to occur after the beat
Leap of 3rd:
Fill in the 3rd with a passing tone
Add an appoggiatura by leaping one step beyond the note of resolution, placing the appogiatura on the beat, displacing the note of resolution to occur after the beat
Leaps of 4th or larger: do not embellish (for now)
